**The Esoteric Canon of the Six Yin Caverns of the Mysterious Transformations of the Hidden Dao: The Authentic Classic of Dunjia, Scroll One**

The Most High said:
Those who seek transmission must first bathe and purify the body, solemnly light incense before the stove, gaze upon the Northern Asterism, and with reverent heart offer prayers to the fragrant smoke. They shall invoke the August Jade Emperor of the Vast Heaven, the Most High Mysterious Maiden of the Nine Heavens, and the Sacred Master, the Mysterious Heavenly Emperor, saying:

*"I, a disciple of the Most High, having received the* **Scripture of the Six Yin Caverns of the Mysterious Jade Maiden of the Most High***, have taken refuge in its precepts and wear its teachings close to my person, practicing in accordance with its methods. I humbly pray that Heaven may bestow blessings and protection, that Earth may grant auspicious omens, that the Great Dao may swiftly be accomplished, and that my heart’s vows may soon be fulfilled.*

*After receiving this canon, I shall forever uphold its practice, never speaking lightly or deceitfully, never recklessly disclosing it to unworthy persons, never employing it for perverse ends, nor seeking杂慕. From the moment I obtain this method, I vow to seek longevity, to benefit the common people, to aid the nation and succor the people, to retreat into solitude and purity, and to dispel demons and slay evil. May the Three Heavens deign to witness this, and may all phenomena come to know it. Grant me communion with the numinous, that my aspirations may be realized. Should I ever act recklessly or practice sorcery, I willingly submit to Heaven’s punishment, and the Sacred Perfected shall withhold their protection."*

*Swiftly, swiftly, in accordance with the statutes and ordinances, let it be done.*

After transmission, on an auspicious day, prepare seven oil-and-flour cakes, seven *huanxi* sweet dumplings, seven strips of pure cloth, and seven cups of jujube broth. At the second watch, when the stars and moon shine brightly, arrange seven offerings beneath the Northern Dipper, burning abundant incense in a blazing fire. Holding this canon, bow one hundred times and proclaim:

*"I pour forth my heart and devote my will, gathering qi and uniting with the spirit. I bow twice and offer incense, pledging my sincerity in this oath. I am a child of the Most High, having long practiced purity and stillness, earnestly discerning the heart of Heaven. I wish to depart the mundane world and return to Penglai. With utmost reverence, I make this supplication, humbly beseeching the True Compassion to look down with mercy and witness my vow.*

*On this day of such-and-such month and year, I have received the* **Scripture of the Six Yin Caverns of the Mysterious Jade Maiden of the Most High***. I now wish to practice its teachings and pray for the witness of this covenant. Having received this method, I dare not treat it lightly. Unless in dire need to save others, I swear never to misuse it."*

I now reverently face Your august presence and solemnly pledge these words. Should I fail to uphold them, I willingly accept punishment. In all matters of urgency or delay, I pray for Your protection and aid. I advance to offer incense and bow twice, then softly invoke:

*"I beseech the two or three Jade Maidens to serve as my envoys—ascending to the celestial court, descending to traverse the world, dispatching flying talismans and swift seals, expelling evil and slaying demons, fulfilling all tasks I command. Humbly I implore Your august compassion to look down with favor and witness my plea."*

Again I offer incense and bow twice, then invoke:

*"The matters I have declared are now laid before Your presence. Humbly I pray for Your mighty power to grant constant protection and blessing."*

After bowing, I withdraw the incense altar. On a chosen auspicious day, I prepare a portion of tea, a cup of wine, and a plate of fruit. At the second watch, unseen by others, I face the Northern Asterism beneath the eaves, set up the incense altar, offer incense, and bow twice, then reverently invoke:

*"True Martial Spirit of the North, Perfected Sovereign of Numinous Response, this night and hour, I beseech You to descend in majesty. I have a humble matter to present before Your presence with a hundred bows. I uphold the mandate of the Most High, practicing the registers of the Dao. I slay ghosts and dispel evil, aid the state and pacify households, seek immortality and study the Dao, succoring the orphaned and impoverished. I wish to practice the* **Scripture of the Six Yin Caverns of the Mysterious Jade Maiden**, *commanding two or three Jade Maidens to harmonize Heaven and Earth and subdue demonic forces. By principle and reason, I seek to fulfill this vow. Humbly I pray that the August Sovereign witness my sincerity and lend Your mighty power. Daring to rely on the exalted Perfected, may I forever abide in the true position. Where my seal is placed, let it be the Daoist sanctuary. Humbly I beseech Your sagely compassion to extend Your sacred virtue."*

Then I form the mudra with both thumbs and invoke:

*"Heaven is serene, Earth is tranquil; yin is turbid, yang is clear.
Eyes blazing, hair unbound, the Tortoise and Serpent unite in form.
Wielding the sacred sword, I sever demonic essences.
Come and dwell in my chamber, presiding over the Six Yin’s majesty.
Hear my invocation, follow my decree.
Eternally guard the central position, protecting until immortality is achieved."*

*Swift as the statutes command!* (Recited seven times.)

Again I offer incense and invoke:

*"I wish the two or three Jade Maidens to serve as my envoys for all exorcistic tasks. May the August Sovereign grant protection, aiding the divine hemp, for which I am deeply fortunate."*

I bow twice, then withdraw the altar and take my leave.

**Grand Ritual of Offering**
On a *guihai* day, first write the petition and talismans to summon the deities. Keep outsiders beyond the precincts. The night before, prepare offerings and offer incense. Face north before the altar, visualize the deities, and knock the teeth together before invoking:

*"I, a disciple of the register of [such-and-such] prefecture, most reverently bow and invoke:
Ancestral Master, True Martial of the North, Perfected Sovereign Who Upholds Sageliness, may Your sagely presence descend to witness the great covenant of the ritual."*

I offer incense and pour wine, then invoke before the Perfected Sovereign of *Dingmao*:

*"I humbly summon the Jade Maiden of* Dingmao*, ‘Foot Day,’ named* Baozhong*, the Perfected Sovereign of Boundless Benevolence and Blessing, to descend to this altar upon smelling my incense."*

I burn incense, burn the *Hetong* talisman, recite my personal incantation, and draw the qi of the proper direction to blow upon it. Next, I invoke:

*"I humbly summon the Jade Maiden of* Dingchou*,* Hei Wushang*, named* Taihe*, the Perfected Sovereign of Horizontal Heaven and Benevolent Actuality, to descend to this altar upon smelling my incense.
I humbly summon the Jade Maiden of* Dinghai*,* Lu Mingji*, named* Guangyang*, the Perfected Sovereign of the Capital Prefecture and Benevolent Origin, to descend to this altar upon smelling my incense.
I humbly summon the Jade Maiden of* Dingyou*,* Jiu Qinling*, named* Zhengyi Yafu Renxiu*, the Perfected Sovereign of Rectitude and Rest, to descend to this altar upon smelling my incense.
I humbly summon the Jade Maiden of* Dingwei*,* Cheng Suling*, named* Xuanying Wubi Renzhi*, the Peerless Perfected Sovereign of Mysterious Radiance, to descend to this altar upon smelling my incense.
I humbly summon the Jade Maiden of* Dingsi*,* Zhu Fucheng*, named* Wenguang Gaoshang Rende*, the Exalted Perfected Sovereign of Cultivated Virtue, to descend to this altar upon smelling my incense."*

*"Now that I have reverently summoned the two or three Jade Maidens, may they deign to descend in majesty. Humbly I beseech Your true numina to condescend to this great transformation, descending in ritual splendor to receive my earnest prayers."*

With the left middle finger and the right *Dasha* mudra, I knock my teeth thirty-six times and recite the *Hidden Words of the Six Yin and Six Ding Jade Maidens and Eight Pure Ones*:

*"Nine qi of the radiant dragon follow the Five Peaks.
The Four Saints of Heavenly Obscurity and the Ten Origins of the Eight Poles.
The hundred spirits of the Dipper and the twelve daily asterisms.
The Six Ding Jade Maidens, may You bestow true radiance to aid the ritual’s commands and restraints.
I invoke the* **Most High Lord Lao** *to thoroughly enforce the statutes and save!"*

(Recited three times in succession.)

I summon each of the Six Ding Jade Maidens by their names and mudras. Then I perform the *Dang* step:

*"Concealing form, hiding traces, I tread my* Dang *and* Kui*.*
*I see them, yet they know not me.
Moving and planting as I will, demons follow at my rebuke.
Swift as water and fire, dancing like wind and thunder.
Transforming marshes into mountains, overturning earth and sky.
My body is firm, tranquil and silent.
For ten thousand ages, I attain long life and merge with the Dao to become immortal."*

*Swift as the statutes of the Dark Maiden of the Nine Heavens command!*

I draw the qi of each direction and blow it into the altar. I invite the Jade Maidens to take their seats according to their positions, burn six talismans of their respective forms in the altar, knock my teeth, close my eyes, and visualize the six Jade Maidens descending to the altar. I bow twice and offer incense, then invoke:

*"After reverently summoning the True Martial Sovereign, I now burn incense to invite the two or three Jade Maidens. Having visualized their descent and seating, I, disciple [Name], bow twice in reverence.
I am a disciple of the* **Most High Lord Lao**, *having long upheld the sagely Dao, desiring eternal life.
I tread the pure and contend with the rules, practicing profound and wondrous deeds.
Ever devoted to the supreme Dao, I receive the mandate to cultivate.
Above, I offer prayers for the souls of my ancestors; below, I relieve the calamities and epidemics of the myriad people.
I uphold the registers of the Dao and practice its restraints.
Now I wish to establish an altar, adorn a purified chamber, and prepare offerings according to the ritual statutes to feast the Perfected Sovereign.
Relying on Your majestic radiance, I humbly beseech Your thorough witness.
I seek to master the principles of immortality, pacify the state and people, enchant water and dispatch talismans to expel evil and govern ghosts.
Above, to aid the state’s needs; below, to support my own destiny."*

For all matters great or small, every act of movement relies on the majestic immortals to serve as messengers. Assist me in my practice and heed my instructions. From east to west, south to north, all shall comply and obey. Call their names and inscribe their seals—upon hearing the invocation, they shall arrive at once. Record their words and never break faith.

Light incense and bow twice, then draw near softly and whisper:
"I bear the command of the Most High and the decree of the Jade Emperor to harmonize the cosmos, pacify and aid the state, raise armies and act, dispatch ghosts and expel evil. Today, I feast the immortal spirits, that they may forever serve as my protective envoys. You must adapt to my strategies and follow my actions. Should any disobey, they shall face the command of the Most High and the decree of the Jade Emperor—severing the spirit’s body and extinguishing the spirit’s virtue."

May the numinous ones, in their wisdom, deign to listen below.
Bow twice more, light incense, and raise the wine.

Next, kneel and prostrate, knocking teeth together, and pray:
"Disciple [Name] humbly encounters this grand assembly’s night and reverently offers sacrifice before the two or three Jade Maidens. I reflect that my nature is innate, my heart bears heaven’s decree, and my original master holds a covenant, a transmission from the Most High. Now, on this grand occasion, I modestly present this cup.

The Wind Earl sweeps clean, the Rain Master purifies the altar. I, your devotee, cherish auspicious omens. Having declared my name and lineage, I wish to receive your true radiance, serve you all my life, and never forget you. Today’s offering includes fine meats, dried delicacies, and fragrant incense—jujubes from Anyi, with small pits and tender flesh; pure, clear wine, its floating froth poured in streams; seasonal fruits; and white rice, the finest grain. Partake of my feast, drink and eat your fill. When sated with wine and food, follow my every move. Whatever I pray for, respond in kind. Ever attend me, ever guard my side. May my wishes prosper and flourish. Wherever I go, may the Perfected accompany me. In concealment or openness, in all journeys, may all be peaceful. Swiftly achieve the great Dao and soon reach the immortal realm. When I suffer, may the Perfected bring auspicious tidings. When I desire, may the Perfected follow and fulfill. Entering enemy lands to protect the state, may all be well. Safeguard my body, and with heaven and earth, endure.

Pour the libation, offer the drunkenness—may it be received with favor.
Hastily, as by the statutes and decrees of the Most High."

Bow twice more and light incense, then recite the personal incantation of your own body. Draw in a breath of qi and blow it upon the seat, secretly saying:
"Jade Maiden of Dingmao, you possess the *Six Yin Classic* and the *True Writ of the Subtle Cavern* of the Most High. You know the names of spirits and the titles of immortals. With the proper method, you summon immortals; with the proper method, you command spirits. Traversing the Three Realms, emerging from darkness into light, in movement and stillness, sitting and lying down, all rely on the immortal Perfected. Summoned, you arrive at once; invoked, you descend immediately. All affairs of the human world, let me hear them clearly. I vow to repay your favor—do not defy me.
Hastily, as by the statutes and decrees."

Recite three times. Draw qi from the Dingmao direction and blow it forth. Then do the same from Dingchou, and likewise for the other directions.

Light incense devoutly and recite the incantation:
"Command the Six Yin, emerge from darkness into light. Fearless and unafraid, unshaken by anything. Follow the turning of my talismans, follow the movement of my seals. Dispel ten thousand calamities, gather blessings upon myself. Active by day, concealed by night—do not disobey my command.
Hastily, as by the statutes and decrees."

After completing this cycle six times, align all to their proper positions. Light incense and bow twice, then take a talisman, roll it into a ball, and consume it with the wine from each position. Bow in gratitude, completing this for all six positions in their proper alignment.

Light incense and recite:
"Now I uphold the method, I am the master, and the Perfected are my disciples. What I dispatch, the spirits shall follow. From this moment onward, never leave my side. Golden coins and cloud steeds shall aid the Perfected’s journey. In all undertakings, do not break faith."

Burn the paper money, then close the altar.

**Memorial Submitting the Classics by Minister Zhao Pu, Right Vice Director of the Chancellery of the Song Dynasty**

Your servant has heard that if heaven’s measure is vast, its covering of all things must be broad; if a person possesses extraordinary talent, establishing merit is not difficult. When the time is ripe with heaven’s favor, it must coincide with a gathering of wind and cloud. Your servant first followed Your Majesty in reclaiming the various states, and though I never matched Xiao He of Han in securing maps and documents for the secret archives, my aspirations were no different.

Moreover, the books stored in the various secret halls may indeed be called arcane. Such works as the *Tai Bai Yin Jing*, *Thirty-Six Ministries of Thunder-Driving Soldiers*, *Qi Circulation Diagrams*, *Twelve Precepts for Summoning Wind and Cloud*, *Tortoise Classic of Water Shrinking*, and *Divine Classic of Uprooting Trees*—these and other secret texts are beyond counting. Yet when one examines them closely, are they not also difficult? Their meanings are abstruse, their words sprawling.

Should some, after receiving the precepts, abstain from drink for life, or others, upon mastering the method, forswear meat for their entire clan—once such vows are taken, no other observances may be followed. Should one’s practice deviate or reverse, dire calamity will strike, beyond swift remedy. In my humble view, this is not yet perfection.

One day, the recluse Liu Han of Mount Luofu sought audience. I said to him: “There exist ancient texts of profound secrecy—have you obtained them?” He replied: “I have.” Liu Han, however, deemed this insufficient and produced a purple satchel from his desk. After burning incense and bowing in reverence, he opened the satchel, drew forth a book, and presented it to me, saying: “The Yellow Emperor, having defeated and slain Chiyou on the wilds of Banquan, concealed this in the celestial treasury. Thereafter, it was transmitted to Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Wen, and Wu. In the Warring States, it was lost. The First Emperor of Qin alone recovered it, enlisting the aid of spirits in secret, and with their support, unified the realm—only to lose it again through his own impiety. Through the Qin and Han dynasties, it passed into the hands of various lords, scattering far and wide.

Alas! Some obtained it but failed to uphold it; others practiced it without reverence—none succeeded. Only five men—Chen Ping of the Former Han, Deng Yu of the Later Han, Zhuge Liang of Shu, Guo Ziyi and Li Jing of Tang—truly grasped it. With utmost care and devotion, they wielded it to devise stratagems beyond mortal comprehension. In every campaign, sally, raid, or ambush, thunder, wind, lightning, and rain would arrive precisely as summoned. Since their time, this method has vanished from the world.

I, your humble servant, have lived in seclusion on Mount Luofu for many years. My late master treasured this text for generations, once admonishing me: ‘Should a sagely and true sovereign arise, and a true adept assist him, you must present this.’ If you, my lord, can practice it with reverence and unwavering faith, your achievements will rival those of the Five Masters.’

I served him for nearly half a year, during which I sometimes heard voices at my ear speaking of matters critical to the state and military. Yet when I turned, no one was there. My doubts dissolved as understanding dawned. The voice declared: ‘I am a spirit of the Six Jia. Do not doubt.’ From then on, my reverence deepened, and the whispers at my ear—reports of daily events—became too numerous to recount.

When I later attended Your Majesty in reclaiming the rebel lands, our advance was as effortless as splitting bamboo. This was not due to my own cunning or foresight, but to the power of the Six Spirits. On campaign, Wang Quanfu, Cui Yandi, Liu Guangyi, Cao Bin, and others knew only that I served these spirits. I would tell them: ‘On such-and-such a day, rain; on another, wind; on yet another, fire will consume the enemy camp.’ Not once did I err. This method is a swift and wondrous shortcut to the mysterious—how could Liu Han have been an ordinary man? Later, he vanished without trace, as if spirited away. Could it be that Heaven itself bestowed this upon our Song?

This text distills the secrets of all schools, a truly esoteric and untransmitted work. I have recorded its contents faithfully and now humbly submit it for Your Majesty’s perusal. From beginning to end, its incantations and talismans number little more than a thousand characters. I beseech Your Majesty to store it in the Jade Coffer, that it may perpetually safeguard the dynasty for ten thousand years, by the grace of the divine.

On the first day of the seventh month of the fourth year of the *Kaibao* era, by imperial decree, it was sealed in the Jade Coffer and placed in the Secret Archives.

*Preface to the Origin of the* Divine Classic of the Six Jia

In ancient times, Chiyou rebelled, and the Yellow Emperor fought him repeatedly without success. The Emperor said: “I have heard that in the age of Fuxi, the world knew no war...”

Now, Chiyou was but a commoner who had spawned malevolent qi, and though I attacked him repeatedly, I could not prevail—this was my failure. Suddenly, before my eyes, a five-colored cloud descended from the sky. From within the cloud emerged six jade maidens bearing a book, and two youths who declared: “By the sacred command of the Nine Heavens’ Mysterious Maiden, we present the *Three Scrolls of the Classic of the Six Jia Talismans*, that your wish to subdue him may be fulfilled.” This text reveals the fortunes and misfortunes of Heaven and Earth, the auspices and omens of the Eight Trigrams. It discerns the shifts of wind and cloud, recognizes the success or failure of qi and seasons, observes the waxing and waning of sun and moon, expounds the sequence and inversion of yin and yang, comprehends the good and ill of stars, and knows the victory or defeat of human affairs. This art is the method of ten thousand transformations.

The Emperor knelt in reverence to receive it, whereupon the two youths and the jade maidens ascended upon the cloud and departed. The Emperor then opened the case and obtained the *Three Scrolls of the Classic of the Yin Talismans*. The upper scroll expounds the arts of immortals refining the elixir and embracing the One, teaching the methods of longevity. The middle scroll sets forth the ways to pacify the realm, stabilize the state, and comfort the people. The lower scroll discusses matters of warfare and conquest, for the Six Jia is the method of the Mysterious Maiden.

Having received it, the Emperor established an altar, forged seals and swords, and, following its precepts, battled Chiyou on the fields of Zhuolu. Thereafter, he achieved victory and concealed the text within the Golden Hall. Later, during great upheaval, it was retrieved by Chaohuang Yang and transmitted to the mortal world. Those who obtain it are blessed by karmic fortune; those who encounter it prevail as if by divine power. It must be guarded with care and never passed to the unworthy.

The Six Ding spirits are the true deities of the world, unlike ordinary beings. The Azure Dragon, Hall of Light, and Sun spirits, ever attendant upon the jade maidens, are summoned to serve within Heaven and Earth. To conceal one’s form and vanish, hold a blade in the left hand, hold the breath, and with the right hand trace a circle. If the evil one is within, draw a six-foot enclosure outside; if the evil one is without, draw it inside. In the wilds, construct the enclosure there and transform the spirits. Use six rods, each one foot and two inches long. Arrange them in sequence according to the Azure Dragon of each ten-day period, placing the counting rods directly before the Jade Maiden’s gate. With the left hand, draw the rods across to seal the gate, then depart through the Heavenly Gate and Earthly Portal. Once the gate is sealed, the body’s form is concealed.

For each rod, envision a person in the position of the *zi* hour. When the Jade Maiden reaches the Greater Yin, dwell upon the thought that outsiders cannot see you. First recite the incantation to purify mouth and body, form the seal with the left hand, grasp the sword in the right, step the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper, loosen the hair, and brandish the sword. After reciting the purification incantations, close the eyes, silently intone the names of the Seven Stars once, and sever the connection with the local earth deity. When reciting the incantation, draw qi from the direction and blow it forth; advance and retreat while pinching fire. This method is employed in military maneuvers—whether facing inauspicious spirits or malevolent forces, one may vanish into the earth to evade them. Outnumbered or surrounded by ten thousand soldiers, gaze toward the Celestial Stem, draw qi from the indicated direction, and depart; a thousand troops will not perceive you, nor ten thousand see you. This esoteric oral transmission is priceless, its secrets not to be divulged for any treasure. It is the nation’s safeguard, never to be revealed to others.

*End of the First Scroll of the* True Classic of the Six Yin Cavern’s Subtle Transformations of the Hidden Dao

*The Upper Transmission of the* Mysterious Cavern Classic of the Six Exclusions and Jade Maiden

The Most High Lord Lao said: To enter the Dao, one must first delve into its profundities. The subtle and abstruse principles—mobilizing troops, setting forth, guarding the Dao and concealing the form, dispelling evil and expelling wickedness, preserving and protecting the original true—are the most essential of my gates, the means to ascend to the ranks of immortals. Moreover, this method opens the profound path of the pure Heaven and penetrates the abstruse depths of the turbid Earth. Its principles illuminate past and present, its Dao crowns all arts.

For the self, it brings benefit: one may approach officials and superiors, gain audience with kings and nobles, expel ghosts and avert calamities, attract blessings and summon fortune, dispatch flying talismans and moving seals, subdue raging demons, seek the Dao and attain immortality, and act as one desires. For the state, it brings benefit: one may mobilize troops, establish order and discipline, mitigate floods and droughts, eradicate famine and suffering, inspire dreams in kings and lords, harmonize the hearts of all beings, traverse waters and scale mountains, and traverse perilous paths in seclusion. Without this method, how could one ascend to the profound principles so effortlessly?

The Most High Lord Lao said: I transmit this classic and its methods to circulate among humankind, to serve the needs of the virtuous. Those who are not its proper recipients must not privately peruse it. It may be shared with one’s disciples at the cost of a thousand gold, but the *Six Yin Classic* must never be revealed. From ancient times to the present, there has never been one who did not employ this method to attain the Dao. Should it be misused by guards, soldiers, or officials, retribution will swiftly follow—misfortune, stagnation, calamity, and adversity will arise. If one who is not of the Dao, though sincere and offering worldly wealth, transmits it carelessly, the punishment shall be doubled.

The Most High Lord Lao said: Those who wish to transmit this method must first bathe and purify themselves, approaching with solemnity. Light incense at the stove, gaze toward the Northern Asterism, and direct the heart in prayer. The disciple of the Most High declares: On such-and-such a year, month, and day, I received the *Mysterious Cavern Classic of the Six Exclusions and Jade Maiden*. I humbly pray that Heaven bestow blessings and protection, that Earth grant auspicious fortune, that the Great Dao be swiftly accomplished, and that my wishes be soon fulfilled.

After receiving this classic and its methods, the disciple vows to practice it perpetually, never to speak lightly or deceitfully, never to recklessly reveal it to the unworthy, never to employ it for perverse ends, and never to seek杂慕. Having obtained this method, the disciple aspires to seek longevity, benefit the people, aid the state, retreat from the turbid and enter the pure, and eradicate demons and slay evil.

May the Three Heavens bear witness in their great clarity, and may all things under heaven come to know. Bestow upon this disciple the power of spiritual communion, that my intentions may be fulfilled. Should I ever recklessly engage in demonic or perverse acts, I willingly accept the punishment of Heaven, and the sagely immortals shall withhold their protection. Hasten now, as the law commands!

**The Essential Secrets of the Six Yin**
The Six Yin correspond to the yin aspects of the Six Jia. The yin of Jiazi is Dingmao; the yin of Jiaxu is Dingchou; the yin of Jiashen is Dinghai; the yin of Jiawu is Dingyou; the yin of Jiachen is Dingwei; and the yin of Jialin is Dingsi. The Six Ding constitute the Six Yin, just as the Six Jia serve as the yang generals, while the Six Ding are the yin spirits. The reason for employing the Six Ding rather than the Six Yang is that yin represents *wu* (non-being). *Wu* possesses the power of transformation—it can be both existent and non-existent, moving between life and death, and encompassing both concealment and revelation. Like the use of military strategy in war, the Six Yin are formless, yet their application yields immediate response.

Those who walk the Dao employ yin, while those without the Dao employ yang. Yang can be measured, but yin remains unfathomable. The preceding scroll exclusively describes the rites for invoking the Six Ding.

Some may ask: Since the Six Ding are formless, why perform rites for them? The answer lies in the union of form and formlessness—by offering sacrifices to the formless spirits, the tangible and intangible merge. Thus, one visualizes the spirits, clacks the teeth, silently recites the invocation, and verbally petitions them, aided by fragrant wine and fine offerings. Following the prescribed method ensures spiritual resonance.

In ancient times, when the Yellow Emperor waged seventy-two battles against Chiyou, he fell into a deep slumber during the day and dreamed of a divine being who taught him a secret method. Upon awakening, he found the method within a sealed pouch, titled *The Six Yin Cavern Secrets*—the esoteric art of the Six Ding, a system of the Six Jia’s flying palaces and transformative techniques. By adhering to this method, he ultimately vanquished Chiyou. This is the orthodox and mysterious art of the Supreme Unity and Primordial Perfection, not a demonic or perverse practice.

Those who receive its transmission must submit a memorial to the Celestial Bureau, presenting it to the Supreme Emperor, and swear an oath never to recklessly invoke demonic or perverse acts. Should one act deceitfully or improperly, the Six Ding spirits will hold them accountable, and they shall incur the severe punishment of Heaven. Only with a rectified heart and conduct can one employ this method effectively.

The Most High Lord Lao said: In the era of Great Peace, this method was bestowed by the Nine Heavens’ Mysterious Maiden upon the Youxiong clan. The Youxiong clan passed it to Feng Hou, who transmitted it to the Great Mystery Master Yellowstone Elder, who in turn bestowed it upon Zhang Zifang. Since its dissemination among humanity, it has been transmitted to those deemed worthy.

**Names, Attires, and Colors of the Six Ding Jade Maidens**
The Dingmao Jade Maiden is named *Zu Ri Zhi*, also called *Ding Wenming*, styled *Baozhong* or *Rengao*, and titled *Wuji Renfu Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of Limitless Benevolence and Blessing). **Duties of the Six Ding Jade Maidens**
The Dingmao Jade Maiden governs plants and trees. She can summon winds, rains, mists, and fogs to obscure paths, dispel droughts and plagues, and nurture crops. In heaven, she presides over the green qi of wood and the vitality of spring, guarding the human liver and ethereal soul, corresponding to azure stone.

The Dingchou Jade Maiden governs insects and beasts. She can mobilize treasures and reveal hidden stores, as well as enhance the growth of medicinal herbs to heal human ailments. In heaven, she presides over the central qi of the five grains and the four seasons, guarding the human *niwan* (mud-pill palace), corresponding to jasper.

The Dinghai Jade Maiden governs mountains and rivers. She can move Mount Tai, reduce it to a small hill, block roads, or dredge rivers and canals.

The Dinghai Jade Maiden can also split metals and stones and cleave the earth to open paths. In heaven, she presides over the black qi of water and the storage of winter, guarding the essence and kidneys, corresponding to dark stone.

The Dingyou Jade Maiden governs rivers and seas. She can stir winds and waves, scour sands to breach banks, and turn back tides to engulf the sun. She can also blow a single leaf into a boat of olive wood to ferry people across. In heaven, she presides over the white qi of metal and the harvest of autumn, guarding the lungs and corporeal soul, corresponding to white stone.

The Dingwei Jade Maiden governs mountains and waterways. She can transform yin soldiers to aid in battles and rescue those in peril—whether from childbirth, water, fire, or weapons. In heaven, she presides over the yellow qi of earth’s virtue, the surplus of the four seasons, guarding the spleen and stomach, corresponding to yellow stone.

The Dingsi Jade Maiden governs cities and altars. She can arrange formations to break sieges and capture cities or fortresses. She can also exhale to cure untimely chills and fevers. In heaven, she presides over the red qi of fire and the growth of summer, guarding the human heart and spirit, corresponding to red stone.

Finally, nail the remaining six stakes, each two feet and five inches long, and drape them with six strips of clean cloth.

Inscribe each position with its respective talisman, ensuring all six face outward from the altar while their backs point inward. **The Essential Secrets of the Six Yin**
The Six Yin correspond to the yin aspects of the Six Jia. The yin of Jiazi is Dingmao; the yin of Jiaxu is Dingchou; the yin of Jiashen is Dinghai; the yin of Jiawu is Dingyou; the yin of Jiachen is Dingwei; and the yin of Jialin is Dingsi. The Six Ding constitute the Six Yin, just as the Six Jia serve as the yang generals, while the Six Ding are the yin spirits. The reason for employing the Six Ding rather than the Six Yang is that yin represents *wu* (non-being). *Wu* possesses the power of transformation—it can be both existent and non-existent, moving between life and death, and encompassing both concealment and revelation. Like the use of military strategy in war, the Six Yin are formless, yet their application yields immediate response.

Those who walk the Dao employ yin, while those without the Dao employ yang. Yang can be measured, but yin remains unfathomable. The preceding scroll exclusively describes the rites for invoking the Six Ding.

Some may ask: Since the Six Ding are formless, why perform rites for them? The answer lies in the union of form and formlessness—by offering sacrifices to the formless spirits, the tangible and intangible merge. Thus, one visualizes the spirits, clacks the teeth, silently recites the invocation, and verbally petitions them, aided by fragrant wine and fine offerings. Following the prescribed method ensures spiritual resonance.

In ancient times, when the Yellow Emperor waged seventy-two battles against Chiyou, he fell into a deep slumber during the day and dreamed of a divine being who taught him a secret method. Upon awakening, he found the method within a sealed pouch, titled *The Six Yin Cavern Secrets*—the esoteric art of the Six Ding, a system of the Six Jia’s flying palaces and transformative techniques. By adhering to this method, he ultimately vanquished Chiyou. This is the orthodox and mysterious art of the Supreme Unity and Primordial Perfection, not a demonic or perverse practice.

Those who receive its transmission must submit a memorial to the Celestial Bureau, presenting it to the Supreme Emperor, and swear an oath never to recklessly invoke demonic or perverse acts. Should one act deceitfully or improperly, the Six Ding spirits will hold them accountable, and they shall incur the severe punishment of Heaven. Only with a rectified heart and conduct can one employ this method effectively.

The Most High Lord Lao said: In the era of Great Peace, this method was bestowed by the Nine Heavens’ Mysterious Maiden upon the Youxiong clan. The Youxiong clan passed it to Feng Hou, who transmitted it to the Great Mystery Master Yellowstone Elder, who in turn bestowed it upon Zhang Zifang. Since its dissemination among humanity, it has been transmitted to those deemed worthy.

**Names, Attires, and Colors of the Six Ding Jade Maidens**
The Dingmao Jade Maiden is named *Zu Ri Zhi*, also called *Ding Wenming*, styled *Baozhong* or *Rengao*, and titled *Wuji Renfu Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of Limitless Benevolence and Blessing). Her appearance: clad in a green court robe, wearing a rabbit-headed crown, a yellow skirt, with knitted brows. In her left hand, she holds a wish-fulfilling pearl, and in her right, a sword. She descends on Zichou days to serve in the eastern halls of households.

The Dingchou Jade Maiden is named *Hei Wushang*, also called *Ding Wengong*, styled *Taihe* or *Rengui*, and titled *Hengtian Renshi Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of Heaven-Spanning Benevolence and Fruitfulness). Her appearance: dressed in a blue-green court robe, wearing a cow-headed crown and a pale yellow skirt, holding a halberd or smiling gently. She descends on Yinmao days to serve in the northeastern cattle pens or the abodes of the Controller of Fate.

The Dinghai Jade Maiden is named *Lu Mingji*, also called *Ding Wentong*, styled *Guangyang* or *Renhe*, and titled *Dufu Renyuan Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of the Capital’s Benevolent Origin). Her appearance: clad in a black court robe, wearing a pig-headed crown and a pale yellow skirt, holding immortal fruits and a sword. She descends on Chensi days to serve in the northern corners of households, near kitchens or latrines.

The Dingyou Jade Maiden is named *Jiu Qinling*, also called *Ding Wenqing*, styled *Zhengyi* or *Renxiu*, and titled *Yafu Renxiu Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of Subordinate Benevolence and Rest). Her appearance: radiant in complexion, wearing a chicken-headed crown, a white silk court robe, and a pale yellow skirt, with knitted brows, holding two crossbow bolts. She descends on Xuhai days to serve in the western halls of households.

The Dingwei Jade Maiden is named *Cheng Suling*, also called *Ding Jitong*, styled *Xuanying* or *Rengong*, and titled *Wubi Renzhi Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of Incomparable Benevolence and Arrival). Her appearance: radiant in complexion, wearing a sheep-headed crown, a pink court robe, and a yellow skirt, smiling gently, holding a pair of halberds or a sword. She descends on Wuwei days to serve in the southern halls of households.

The Dingsi Jade Maiden is named *Zhu Fucheng*, also called *Ding Tingqing*, styled *Wenguang* or *Renjing*, and titled *Gaoshang Rende Zhenjun* (Perfected Lord of Lofty Benevolence and Virtue). Her appearance: dressed in a green court robe and a red skirt, wearing a snake-tailed crown, holding a long spear, and laughing heartily. She descends on Shenyou days to serve in the southeastern gardens and pavilions of households.

The Six Ding Yin Spirits, the Jade Maidens, each govern their respective domains. They wear crowns and tassels, green robes, white garments, and vermilion shoes, wielding swords, bows, and arrows. Should they manifest in the homes of their devotees on the days of the Six Ding, men and women who witness them must not be alarmed or shout in fear, lest they offend the spirits.

**Duties of the Six Ding Jade Maidens**
The Dingmao Jade Maiden governs plants and trees. She can summon winds, rains, mists, and fogs to obscure paths, dispel droughts and plagues, and nurture crops. In heaven, she presides over the green qi of wood and the vitality of spring, guarding the human liver and ethereal soul, corresponding to azure stone.

The Dingchou Jade Maiden governs insects and beasts. She can mobilize treasures and reveal hidden stores, as well as enhance the growth of medicinal herbs to heal human ailments. In heaven, she presides over the central qi of the five grains and the four seasons, guarding the human *niwan* (mud-pill palace), corresponding to jasper.

The Dinghai Jade Maiden governs mountains and rivers. She can move Mount Tai, reduce it to a small hill, block roads, or dredge rivers and canals.

On each talisman, depict the true form of the Jade Maiden standing upright. When treating illness, do not use the seal at the head.

This talisman guides the nine generations of ancestors and the seven generations of forebears into the netherworld, as well as all departed souls.
